trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the **AppBackend** project that you created in the **Notify Users** tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the **AppBackend** project that you created in the **Notify Users** tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In Notifications.cs, replace the whole **Notifications** class with the following code.
trans-unit.target: In Notifications.cs, replace the whole **Notifications** class with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to replace the placeholders with your connection string (with full access) for your notification hub, and the hub name.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to replace the placeholders with your connection string (with full access) for your notification hub, and the hub name.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain these values from the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: You can obtain these values from the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: This module now represents the different secure notifications that will be sent.
trans-unit.target: This module now represents the different secure notifications that will be sent.

trans-unit.source: In a complete implementation, the notifications will be stored in a database; for simplicity, in this case we store them in memory.
trans-unit.target: In a complete implementation, the notifications will be stored in a database; for simplicity, in this case we store them in memory.

trans-unit.source: In NotificationsController.cs, replace the code inside the **NotificationsController** class definition with the following code.
trans-unit.target: In NotificationsController.cs, replace the code inside the **NotificationsController** class definition with the following code.

trans-unit.source: This component implements a way for the device to retrieve the notification securely, and also provides a way (for the purposes of this tutorial) to trigger a secure push to your devices.
trans-unit.target: This component implements a way for the device to retrieve the notification securely, and also provides a way (for the purposes of this tutorial) to trigger a secure push to your devices.

trans-unit.source: Note that when sending the notification to the notification hub, we only send a raw notification with the ID of the notification (and no actual message):
trans-unit.target: Note that when sending the notification to the notification hub, we only send a raw notification with the ID of the notification (and no actual message):

trans-unit.source: Note that the `Post` method now does not send a toast notification.
trans-unit.target: Note that the `Post` method now does not send a toast notification.

trans-unit.source: It sends a raw notification that contains only the notification ID, and not any sensitive content.
trans-unit.target: It sends a raw notification that contains only the notification ID, and not any sensitive content.

trans-unit.source: Also, make sure to comment the send operation for the platforms for which you do not have credentials configured on your notification hub, as they will result in errors.
trans-unit.target: Also, make sure to comment the send operation for the platforms for which you do not have credentials configured on your notification hub, as they will result in errors.

trans-unit.source: Now we will re-deploy this app to an Azure Website in order to make it accessible from all devices.
trans-unit.target: Now we will re-deploy this app to an Azure Website in order to make it accessible from all devices.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the **AppBackend** project and select **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the **AppBackend** project and select **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Select Azure Website as your publish target.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure Website as your publish target.

trans-unit.source: Log in with your Azure account and select an existing or new Website, and make a note of the **destination URL** property in the **Connection** tab.
trans-unit.target: Log in with your Azure account and select an existing or new Website, and make a note of the **destination URL** property in the **Connection** tab.

trans-unit.source: We will refer to this URL as your *backend endpoint* later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: We will refer to this URL as your *backend endpoint* later in this tutorial.
